newsitem.title: USA: Goldman, Salomon held merger talks in '95 - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Goldman, Salomon held merger talks in '95 - WSJ.

text.p: Goldman, Sachs & Co held talks nearly two years ago with Salamon Inc about merging the companies and becoming public in the process, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the talks.

The paper reported in its electronic edition that the talks -- held amid a merger wave on Wall Street -- were purely exploratory and did not include a discussion of the 11.0 percent stake held by Kamehameha Schools/Bishop Estate, the large Hawaiian trust.
The talks fell apart because the two companies had vastly different corporate cultures and Goldman sought an upper hand in running the merged firm, the paper said.
The talks show that taking itself public is not the only route Goldman can go should it want to become a public company, the paper added.
They also show how Salomon, whose shares closed down $1-7/8 Monday at $63-1/2, could find itself swept up in the merger wave too, the paper said.
Officials from both Goldman, Sachs and Salomon had no comment on the matter, the paper said.
